fields.description: An increase in gene expression leading to higher levels of gene product.
A decrease in gene expression resulting in lower levels of gene product.
A complete loss of function of a gene due to deletion or other genetic modifications.
Addition of one or more nucleotide base pairs into a DNA sequence.
Removal of one or more nucleotide base pairs from a DNA sequence.
A mutation that involves a change in a single nucleotide base pair in the DNA sequence.
A type of point mutation where one nucleotide is replaced by another.
A mutation that shifts the reading frame of the genetic code, often leading to significant changes in the resulting protein.
An increase in the number of copies of a particular gene.
The joining of two separate genes to form a new hybrid gene.
A genetic abnormality caused by rearrangement of parts between nonhomologous chromosomes.
A mutation that results in the presence of one or more extra copies of a gene or region of a chromosome.
Changes in gene expression caused by mechanisms other than changes in the DNA sequence, such as DNA methylation or histone modification.
An increase in the production of a gene product, often due to genetic modification or other regulatory changes.
The process of reducing or completely shutting down the expression of a gene.
A gene knockout that can be activated or deactivated in response to specific conditions or signals.
A mutagenesis technique where a foreign DNA sequence is inserted into a genome to induce mutations.
